elements.content: The stability constants (log β) of 1:1 uranyl complexes with three N,O-mixed donor ligands (L = 2,2′-dipyridyl-6,6′-dicarboxylate, 3,3′-dimethyl-2,2′-bipyridine-6,6′-dicarboxylate, and 1,10-phenanthroline-2,9-dicarboxylate, denoted as BiPDA, DmBiPDA, and PhenDA, respectively) in aqueous and DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O solutions were determined by spectrophotometry in 0.1 M tetraethylammonium perchlorate. The effects of ligand preorganization, steric hindrance, and solvation on the binding strength of U­(VI) with the three ligands were discussed. In aqueous solution, PhenDA forms stronger complexes with U­(VI) than BiPDA due to its well-preorganized structure. In DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O solution, in contrast, the strong solvation effect of DMSO on the ligands reduces the energy gap between the trans- and cis-conformations of BiPDA, resulting in log β­(UO2­(BiPDA)) > log β­(UO2­(PhenDA)). The steric hindrance of methyl groups on DmBiPDA makes the complex UO2­(DmBiPDA) of the lowest stability in both aqueous and DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O solutions. Single-crystal structural data of U­(VI) complexes with the three ligands indicate that the ligand coordinates with UO2 2+ via aromatic nitrogen atoms and carboxylate oxygen atoms. There is no clear correlation between the trend of the stability constants in solutions and the U–N/O bond lengths of the three crystal complexes. Nevertheless, DmBiPDA coordinates to UO2 2+ in a high-strain fashion as a result of the steric hindrance of methyl groups while BiPDA in a low-strain fashion, which is in accordance with the relative complexation strength of the two respective complexes. The results from this work help us understand the effect of ligand preorganization and solvation on the binding strength of actinides with multidentate N,O-mixed ligands in solid and solutions, which is of importance in designing ligands for the partitioning of actinides from nuclear wastes.

In aqueous solution, PhenDA forms stronger complexes with U(VI) than BiPDA due to its well-preorganized structure. In DMSO/20%(v)H2O solution, in contrast, the strong solvation effect of DMSO on the ligands reduces the energy gap between the trans- and cis-conformations of BiPDA, resulting in log β(UO2(BiPDA)) > log β(UO2(PhenDA)). The steric hindrance of methyl groups on DmBiPDA makes the complex UO2(DmBiPDA) of the lowest stability in both aqueous and DMSO/20%(v)H2O solutions. Single-crystal structural data of U(VI) complexes with the three ligands indicate that the ligand coordinates with UO2 2+ via aromatic nitrogen atoms and carboxylate oxygen atoms. There is no clear correlation between the trend of the stability constants in solutions and the U-N/O bond lengths of the three crystal complexes. Nevertheless, DmBiPDA coordinates to UO2 2+ in a high-strain fashion as a result of the steric hindrance of methyl groups while BiPDA in a low-strain fashion, which is in accordance with the relative complexation strength of the two respective complexes. The results from this work help us understand the effect of ligand preorganization and solvation on the binding strength of actinides with multidentate N,O-mixed ligands in solid and solutions, which is of importance in designing ligands for the partitioning of actinides from nuclear wastes.

elements.content: The stability constants (log β) of 1:1 uranyl complexes with three mixed N- and O-donor analogue ligands in aqueous and DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O solutions were determined, and two crystal structures of the U­(VI) complexes were also obtained. The effects of ligand preorganization, steric hindrance, and solvation on the binding strengths and the crystal structures were discussed.
elements.clean_text: The stability constants (log β) of 1:1 uranyl complexes with three mixed N- and O-donor analogue ligands in aqueous and DMSO/20%(v)H2O solutions were determined, and two crystal structures of the U(VI) complexes were also obtained. The effects of ligand preorganization, steric hindrance, and solvation on the binding strengths and the crystal structures were discussed.

elements.content: Ligands bearing N,O-mixed donors are potential separation reagents used in the GANEX process (Group ActiNides EXtraction) and thus have been drawing great interests from nuclear chemists. 2,2′-Bipyridine-6,6′-dicarboxylic acid (H2BiPDA, a) and 1,10-phenanthroline-2,9-dicarboxylic acid (H2PhenDA, c) as well as their diamide derivatives are the most intensively investigated N,O-mixed donor ligands. Studies on BiPDA so far mainly focused on the preparation and characterization of its metal–organic materials. For PhenDA, the interaction strength to some metal ions in aqueous solutions and the complex structures in solid were reported in the literature. For example, Hancock and co-workers determined the stability constants of the 1:1 complexes of PhenDA with transition metals and lanthanides in aqueous solutions, discussing the promotion of donor preorganization on the affinity with metal ions by comparing the complexation behavior of PhenDA with EDDA (ethylendiiminodiacetic acid). It is noticeable that the N-donors in EDDA are sp3-hybridzed which are quite different from the sp2-hybridized pyridyl N-donors in PhenDA; BiPDA, bearing the same sp2-hybridized pyridyl N-donors but with a less preorganized backbone, is a perfect structural analogue to PhenDA for studying the preorganization effect. Unfortunately, it is challenging to investigate the complexation behavior of BiPDA with metal ions in aqueous solution because BiPDA is nearly insoluble in water (solubility less than 1 × 10–4 M), and thus no corresponding data are available in the literature.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Ligands bearing N,O-mixed donors are potential separation reagents used in the GANEX process (Group ActiNides EXtraction) and thus have been drawing great interests from nuclear chemists. 2,2'-Bipyridine-6,6'-dicarboxylic acid (H2BiPDA, a) and 1,10-phenanthroline-2,9-dicarboxylic acid (H2PhenDA, c) as well as their diamide derivatives are the most intensively investigated N,O-mixed donor ligands. Studies on BiPDA so far mainly focused on the preparation and characterization of its metal-organic materials. For PhenDA, the interaction strength to some metal ions in aqueous solutions and the complex structures in solid were reported in the literature. For example, Hancock and co-workers determined the stability constants of the 1:1 complexes of PhenDA with transition metals and lanthanides in aqueous solutions, discussing the promotion of donor preorganization on the affinity with metal ions by comparing the complexation behavior of PhenDA with EDDA (ethylendiiminodiacetic acid). It is noticeable that the N-donors in EDDA are sp3-hybridzed which are quite different from the sp2-hybridized pyridyl N-donors in PhenDA; BiPDA, bearing the same sp2-hybridized pyridyl N-donors but with a less preorganized backbone, is a perfect structural analogue to PhenDA for studying the preorganization effect. Unfortunately, it is challenging to investigate the complexation behavior of BiPDA with metal ions in aqueous solution because BiPDA is nearly insoluble in water (solubility less than 1 × 10-4 M), and thus no corresponding data are available in the literature.

elements.content: Structures of the three tetradentate N,O-donor ligands. (a) BiPDA: 2,2′-dipyridyl-6,6′-dicarboxylate; (b) DmBiPDA: 3,3′-dimethyl-2,2′-bipyridine-6,6′-dicarboxylate; (c) PhenDA: 1,10-phenanthroline-2,9-dicarboxylate.
elements.clean_text: 1  Structures of the three tetradentate N,O-donor ligands. (a) BiPDA: 2,2'-dipyridyl-6,6'-dicarboxylate; (b) DmBiPDA: 3,3'-dimethyl-2,2'-bipyridine-6,6'-dicarboxylate; (c) PhenDA: 1,10-phenanthroline-2,9-dicarboxylate.

elements.content: Quantitative description of the interaction of U­(VI) with ligands used in the nuclear fuel cycle or existing in the environment is one of the most important tasks in actinides chemistry. So far, the exact stability constants (denoted as log β) of U­(VI)/​BiPDA complexes have yet to be determined, while log β­(UO2­(PhenDA)) = 16.5(1) at I = 0 is the only reported value of the U­(VI)/​PhenDA complex. Moreover, since polar fluorinated solvents (such as m-nitrobenzotrifluoride) are usually selected as diluents to yield high extraction efficiency for the extraction of actinides and lanthanides by diamide derivatives of BiPDA and PhenDA, it is also important to investigate the complexation of actinides with such mixed N,O-donor ligands in polar solvents. Interests have been growing on the speciation and structure of actinides/​lanthanides in nonaqueous solvents like DMSO, which could provide valuable information for the development of novel separation processes.
elements.clean_text: Quantitative description of the interaction of U(VI) with ligands used in the nuclear fuel cycle or existing in the environment is one of the most important tasks in actinides chemistry. So far, the exact stability constants (denoted as log β) of U(VI)/BiPDA complexes have yet to be determined, while log β(UO2(PhenDA)) = 16.5(1) at I = 0 is the only reported value of the U(VI)/PhenDA complex. Moreover, since polar fluorinated solvents (such as m-nitrobenzotrifluoride) are usually selected as diluents to yield high extraction efficiency for the extraction of actinides and lanthanides by diamide derivatives of BiPDA and PhenDA, it is also important to investigate the complexation of actinides with such mixed N,O-donor ligands in polar solvents. Interests have been growing on the speciation and structure of actinides/lanthanides in nonaqueous solvents like DMSO, which could provide valuable information for the development of novel separation processes.

elements.content: In this work, the stability constants of the U­(VI) complexes with a series of three structurally related ligands, BiPDA, PhenDA, and DmBiPDA (3,3′-dimethyl-2,2′-bipyridine-6,6′-dicarboxylate, b), in aqueous solution as well as in DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O solution have been determined by spectrophotometry. DmBiPDA was selected as a transition structure between BiPDA and PhenDA. The rotation of the C–C single bond linking the two pyridine units is expected to be greatly adjusted by the two methyl substituents, and thus, this ligand can be used as a good model to study the steric hindrance effect during complexation. The DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O mixture was selected as the solvent based on the following considerations: (a) to simulate the polar diluents used in biphasic extraction; (b) to ensure sufficient solubility of ligands and their complexes with U­(VI); and (c) reliable values of the autoprotolysis constant (pK w = 18.40, I = 0.1 M) are available in literatures. Moreover, we also report here the synthesis and crystal structures of two novel U­(VI) complexes with BiPDA and DmBiPDA, which have enriched the less-studied structural chemistry of actinide complexes with these tetradentate N,O-mixed donor ligands.
elements.clean_text: In this work, the stability constants of the U(VI) complexes with a series of three structurally related ligands, BiPDA, PhenDA, and DmBiPDA (3,3'-dimethyl-2,2'-bipyridine-6,6'-dicarboxylate, b), in aqueous solution as well as in DMSO/20%(v)H2O solution have been determined by spectrophotometry. DmBiPDA was selected as a transition structure between BiPDA and PhenDA. The rotation of the C-C single bond linking the two pyridine units is expected to be greatly adjusted by the two methyl substituents, and thus, this ligand can be used as a good model to study the steric hindrance effect during complexation. The DMSO/20%(v)H2O mixture was selected as the solvent based on the following considerations: (a) to simulate the polar diluents used in biphasic extraction; (b) to ensure sufficient solubility of ligands and their complexes with U(VI); and (c) reliable values of the autoprotolysis constant (pK w = 18.40, I = 0.1 M) are available in literatures. Moreover, we also report here the synthesis and crystal structures of two novel U(VI) complexes with BiPDA and DmBiPDA, which have enriched the less-studied structural chemistry of actinide complexes with these tetradentate N,O-mixed donor ligands.

elements.content: All chemicals were reagent grade or higher. Boiled Milli-Q water was used in preparation of all solutions. Anhydrous DMSO (99.9%, Sigma-Aldrich) was used without further purification. Tetraethylammonium perchlorate (TEAP, (C2H5)4­N­(ClO4), 99%, TCI) was recrystallized with methanol and dried overnight under vacuum at room temperature. Other organic chemicals, such as H2BiPDA (98%, TCI), H2PhenDA (98%, TCI), and H2DmBiPDA (98%, Marshallton, USA), were dried under vacuum for 24 h at room temperature prior to use. 0.1 M TEAP solution in DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O was prepared as the ionic medium for titration experiments. All experiments were conducted at (25 ± 0.1) °C.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Chemicals

All chemicals were reagent grade or higher. Boiled Milli-Q water was used in preparation of all solutions. Anhydrous DMSO (99.9%, Sigma-Aldrich) was used without further purification. Tetraethylammonium perchlorate (TEAP, (C2H5)4N(ClO4), 99%, TCI) was recrystallized with methanol and dried overnight under vacuum at room temperature. Other organic chemicals, such as H2BiPDA (98%, TCI), H2PhenDA (98%, TCI), and H2DmBiPDA (98%, Marshallton, USA), were dried under vacuum for 24 h at room temperature prior to use. 0.1 M TEAP solution in DMSO/20%(v)H2O was prepared as the ionic medium for titration experiments. All experiments were conducted at (25 ± 0.1) °C.

elements.content: The preparation of the aqueous U­(VI) stock solution ([U] = 0.259 M, [HClO4] = 0.120 M) was described elsewhere. 1.00 mL of the U­(VI) stock solution and 1.00 mL of water were transferred to a 10.00 mL volumetric flask, which was then filled to the scale mark by DMSO at room temperature. The concentrations of uranyl and proton in the DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O solution were 25.9 and 12.0 mM, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of UO2(ClO4)2 Solutions

The preparation of the aqueous U(VI) stock solution ([U] = 0.259 M, [HClO4] = 0.120 M) was described elsewhere. 1.00 mL of the U(VI) stock solution and 1.00 mL of water were transferred to a 10.00 mL volumetric flask, which was then filled to the scale mark by DMSO at room temperature. The concentrations of uranyl and proton in the DMSO/20%(v)H2O solution were 25.9 and 12.0 mM, respectively.

elements.content: DMSO/​20%(v)­H 2 O as solvent: Stock solutions containing 5–10 mM of ligand were prepared by dissolving ligands of known weight in (DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O) using a volumetric flask. Then the working solutions were prepared by quantitative dilution of the stock solution with 0.1 M TEAP/​(DMSO/​(v)­H2O). Water as solvent: Weighed amounts of solid ligands were neutralized by 1.0 M tetraethylammonium hydroxide (TEAOH, electronic grade, Sigma-Aldrich) and then dissolved in water. The working solutions were prepared by quantitative dilution of the stock solution with 0.1 M TEAP in water prior to experiments.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of Ligand Solutions

 DMSO/20%(v)H  2  O as solvent: Stock solutions containing 5-10 mM of ligand were prepared by dissolving ligands of known weight in (DMSO/20%(v)H2O) using a volumetric flask. Then the working solutions were prepared by quantitative dilution of the stock solution with 0.1 M TEAP/(DMSO/(v)H2O). Water as solvent: Weighed amounts of solid ligands were neutralized by 1.0 M tetraethylammonium hydroxide (TEAOH, electronic grade, Sigma-Aldrich) and then dissolved in water. The working solutions were prepared by quantitative dilution of the stock solution with 0.1 M TEAP in water prior to experiments.

elements.content: The protonation constants of BiPDA, DmBiPDA, and PhenDA in 0.1 M TEAP/​(DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O) solution were determined by potentiometric titrations at 25 °C. A computer-controlled titration unit consisiting of a double jacket glass titration cell, a Metrohm dosimat (907 Titrando), and a pH meter equipped with a pH electrode (Metrohm, 6.0229.100) was used. The temperature of the titration cell was maintained at 25.0 ± 0.1 °C by an external circulating water bath. An inert atmosphere was maintained in the titration cell by slowly purging Ar gas into the cell. The original electrode filling solution (3.0 M LiCl in ethanol) was replaced with 1.0 M TEAP in DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O.
elements.clean_text:
Potentiometry

The protonation constants of BiPDA, DmBiPDA, and PhenDA in 0.1 M TEAP/(DMSO/20%(v)H2O) solution were determined by potentiometric titrations at 25 °C. A computer-controlled titration unit consisiting of a double jacket glass titration cell, a Metrohm dosimat (907 Titrando), and a pH meter equipped with a pH electrode (Metrohm, 6.0229.100) was used. The temperature of the titration cell was maintained at 25.0 ± 0.1 °C by an external circulating water bath. An inert atmosphere was maintained in the titration cell by slowly purging Ar gas into the cell. The original electrode filling solution (3.0 M LiCl in ethanol) was replaced with 1.0 M TEAP in DMSO/20%(v)H2O.

elements.content: In methodology, the proton concentration in a titration solution can be potentiometrically obtained with the following equation E = E 0 + R T F ln [ H + ] + γ H [ H + ] where R is the gas constant, F is the Faraday constant, and T is the temperature in kelvin. E is the electromotive force measured through the pH electrode during the titration. The last term is the electrode junction potential for the hydrogen ion (ΔE j,H) and is assumed to be proportional to the concentration of the hydrogen ion. The values of E 0 and γH depend on the specific property of the electrode as well as the ionic strength. The logarithmic function can be approximately represented by the first-order Taylor series; then can be rewritten as the following equation E = E o b v 0 + k · p C H where E obv 0 is the apparently specific constant of the potentiometric cell and k is a constant. The values of E obv 0 and k were obtained by the standard titration of 0.1 M HClO4 with 0.1 M TEAOH in DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O before each experiment. The plots of the EMF readings vs the values of pC H are linear in the range of proton concentration from 10–4 to 10–2 M, with a slope of 60 ± 3 mV.

elements.content: The proton/ligand titration was carried out by adding TEAOH (or HClO4) solution into an acidic (or neutralized) solution containing the ligand. For each addition, EMF was collected with the following criterion: The drift of EMF (ΔE) was less than 0.1 mV over 300 s. Multiple titrations were conducted with solutions of different concentrations of ligand (C L) and total proton (C H). The protonation constants of the ligand were calculated with the program Hyperquad.
elements.clean_text: The proton/ligand titration was carried out by adding TEAOH (or HClO4) solution into an acidic (or neutralized) solution containing the ligand. For each addition, EMF was collected with the following criterion: The drift of EMF (ΔE) was less than 0.1 mV over 300 s. Multiple titrations were conducted with solutions of different concentrations of ligand (C L) and total proton (C H). The protonation constants of the ligand were calculated with the program Hyperquad.

elements.content: Spectrophotometric titrations were conducted at 25 °C on a Cary 6000i spectrophotometer (Agilent, USA) to determine the species and the stability constants of U­(VI) complexes with BiPDA, DmBiPDA, and PhenDA, as well as the protonation constants of BiPDA and DmBiPDA in aqueous solution. The sample and reference cells were wrapped in the double jacket holders to maintain constant temperature by circulating water from a water bath. For a typical titration, 2.0 mL of a solution containing ligand/​proton/​metal was put in the cuvette, into which appropriate aliquots of titrant were added by an injection pump (Harvard 11EX), and the solution was mixed thoroughly for more than 5 min before the spectrum was collected. Prior kinetic experiments showed that the complexation reaction was fast and the absorbance became stable within 1 min of mixing. Multiple titrations were performed with different initial concentrations of reactants in the sample cell. The stability constants were calculated by the nonlinear regression program HypSpec 2009.
elements.clean_text:
UV-vis Spectrophotometry

Spectrophotometric titrations were conducted at 25 °C on a Cary 6000i spectrophotometer (Agilent, USA) to determine the species and the stability constants of U(VI) complexes with BiPDA, DmBiPDA, and PhenDA, as well as the protonation constants of BiPDA and DmBiPDA in aqueous solution. The sample and reference cells were wrapped in the double jacket holders to maintain constant temperature by circulating water from a water bath. For a typical titration, 2.0 mL of a solution containing ligand/proton/metal was put in the cuvette, into which appropriate aliquots of titrant were added by an injection pump (Harvard 11EX), and the solution was mixed thoroughly for more than 5 min before the spectrum was collected. Prior kinetic experiments showed that the complexation reaction was fast and the absorbance became stable within 1 min of mixing. Multiple titrations were performed with different initial concentrations of reactants in the sample cell. The stability constants were calculated by the nonlinear regression program HypSpec 2009.

elements.content: [UO2(BiPDA)­(DMSO)]: 0.05 mL of U­(VI) solution ([U] = 0.259 M, [HClO4] = 0.120 M) was evaporated to dryness at 120 °C on a hot plate, and then dissolved in 1.50 mL of DMSO/​20%H2O. 1.20 mL of 0.01 M BiPDA (neutralized by NaOH) in DMSO/​20%H2O was added. The mixed solution was shaken thoroughly and evaporated at room temperature. Yellowish green crystals appeared in about 5 months. [UO 2 (DmBiPDA)] n : 5.0 mL of an aqueous solution containing 3.91 × 10–3 mmol of DmBiPDA (neutralized by tetraethylammonium hydroxide) and 3.90 × 10–3 mmol of U­(VI) was refluxed at 150 °C on a hot plate for 2 h. Then the mixture was put aside on a hot plate at 100 °C. Yellowish green crystals appeared overnight.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Diffractometry

Crystallization

 [UO2(BiPDA)(DMSO)]: 0.05 mL of U(VI) solution ([U] = 0.259 M, [HClO4] = 0.120 M) was evaporated to dryness at 120 °C on a hot plate, and then dissolved in 1.50 mL of DMSO/20%H2O. 1.20 mL of 0.01 M BiPDA (neutralized by NaOH) in DMSO/20%H2O was added. The mixed solution was shaken thoroughly and evaporated at room temperature. Yellowish green crystals appeared in about 5 months. [UO  2  (DmBiPDA)]   n  : 5.0 mL of an aqueous solution containing 3.91 × 10-3 mmol of DmBiPDA (neutralized by tetraethylammonium hydroxide) and 3.90 × 10-3 mmol of U(VI) was refluxed at 150 °C on a hot plate for 2 h. Then the mixture was put aside on a hot plate at 100 °C. Yellowish green crystals appeared overnight.

elements.content: Representative crystals were mounted on the goniometer, and crystallographic data were collected on a CrysAlisPro (Agilent Technologies, USA) X-ray single-crystal diffractometer at 293 K. The crystallographic data for [UO2­(BiPDA)­(DMSO)] and [UO2­(DmBiPDA)] n are given in , and details of the structural information has been deposited in the Cambridge Structural Database (CCDC 1812979 and 1872138).
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Diffraction

Representative crystals were mounted on the goniometer, and crystallographic data were collected on a CrysAlisPro (Agilent Technologies, USA) X-ray single-crystal diffractometer at 293 K. The crystallographic data for [UO2(BiPDA)(DMSO)] and [UO2(DmBiPDA)] n  are given in , and details of the structural information has been deposited in the Cambridge Structural Database (CCDC 1812979 and 1872138).

The protonation constants of BiPDA, DmBiPDA, and PhenDA in DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O at I = 0.1 M TEAP were determined by potentiometry, while those values of BiPDA and DmBiPDA in aqueous solution at I = 0.1 M TEAP were determined by spectrophotometry. Detailed titrations are described in the Supporting Information (SI), and the results are listed in . The protonation constants of PhenDA in aqueous solution have been determined previously at I = 0.1 M NaClO4, which can be used in this work because the complexation of Na+ with the ligand is insignificant at I = 0.1 M.
elements.clean_text:
Results

Protonation Constants of the Ligands

The protonation constants of BiPDA, DmBiPDA, and PhenDA in DMSO/20%(v)H2O at I = 0.1 M TEAP were determined by potentiometry, while those values of BiPDA and DmBiPDA in aqueous solution at I = 0.1 M TEAP were determined by spectrophotometry. Detailed titrations are described in the Supporting Information (SI), and the results are listed in . The protonation constants of PhenDA in aqueous solution have been determined previously at I = 0.1 M NaClO4, which can be used in this work because the complexation of Na+ with the ligand is insignificant at I = 0.1 M.

In both the aqueous and DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O solutions, the protonation constants (log βHL and log βH2L) follow the order of DmBiPDA > BiPDA > PhenDA. This trend is understandable because: (1) the electron-donating methyl groups on the 3-/3′-position of pyridine make the N atoms in DmBiPDA more negative in charge than those in BiPDA, and (2) the conjugation system of phenanthroline makes the N atoms in PhenDA less negative in charge than those in BiPDA. Moreover, the protonation constants of all the ligands in DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O solution are higher than those in aqueous solution. This observation can be mainly attributed to the less stabilization effect on the deprotonated ligand by hydrogen bonds donated from solvent molecules in DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O solution as compared to that in pure aqueous medium.

This trend is understandable because: (1) the electron-donating methyl groups on the 3-/3'-position of pyridine make the N atoms in DmBiPDA more negative in charge than those in BiPDA, and (2) the conjugation system of phenanthroline makes the N atoms in PhenDA less negative in charge than those in BiPDA. Moreover, the protonation constants of all the ligands in DMSO/20%(v)H2O solution are higher than those in aqueous solution. This observation can be mainly attributed to the less stabilization effect on the deprotonated ligand by hydrogen bonds donated from solvent molecules in DMSO/20%(v)H2O solution as compared to that in pure aqueous medium.

elements.content: The intensity and position of the vibronic spectra of U­(VI) are mainly governed by the geometry of the equatorial coordination and only to a lesser extent affected by the chemical natrue of the ligands. We first tried to determine the stability constants of U­(VI)/​BiPDA complexes by observing the spectral changes of U­(VI) (380–550 nm) along with the addition of ligands. As shown in , significant changes could be observed when R < 1 (R = n BiPDA/​n U, the ligand to metal molar ratio). Along with the addition of BiPDA, a series of well-defined and sharper absorption bands appeared and continuously blue-shifted. Factor analysis suggested the presence of two absorption species in the system, i.e., the free UO2 2+ and the complex UO2L. The fitting converged at log β = 14.93 ± 0.03, and the molar absorption spectra of the free UO2 2+ and the UO2L complex looked reasonable (see the bottom picture in ). However, questions on the reliability of the calculated stability constant were raised when we looked at the Job plot of the titration (the inset of ). A linear decrease of the absorbance at λ = 426 nm was observed until R ≈ 1, indicating that the added L2– along the titration almost quantitatively reacted with UO2 2+ as R approached 1. Evidently, the complexation of UO2 2+ with BiPDA in DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O solution is too strong to be accurately measured using the conditions in this titration experiment.
elements.clean_text:
Stability Constants of U(VI) Complexes

In DMSO/20%(v)H2O Solution

The intensity and position of the vibronic spectra of U(VI) are mainly governed by the geometry of the equatorial coordination and only to a lesser extent affected by the chemical natrue of the ligands. We first tried to determine the stability constants of U(VI)/BiPDA complexes by observing the spectral changes of U(VI) (380-550 nm) along with the addition of ligands. As shown in , significant changes could be observed when R < 1 (R = n BiPDA/n U, the ligand to metal molar ratio). Along with the addition of BiPDA, a series of well-defined and sharper absorption bands appeared and continuously blue-shifted. Factor analysis suggested the presence of two absorption species in the system, i.e., the free UO2 2+ and the complex UO2L. The fitting converged at log β = 14.93 ± 0.03, and the molar absorption spectra of the free UO2 2+ and the UO2L complex looked reasonable (see the bottom picture in ). However, questions on the reliability of the calculated stability constant were raised when we looked at the Job plot of the titration (the inset of ). A linear decrease of the absorbance at λ = 426 nm was observed until R ~ 1, indicating that the added L2- along the titration almost quantitatively reacted with UO2 2+ as R approached 1. Evidently, the complexation of UO2 2+ with BiPDA in DMSO/20%(v)H2O solution is too strong to be accurately measured using the conditions in this titration experiment.

elements.content: To obtain the accurate stability constants of the U­(VI) complexes in DMSO/20%(v)­H2O solution, we further conducted spectrophotometric titrations by probing the change of the ligand absorption spectra (260–350) using U­(VI) solution as the titrant. The titrations were conducted on conditions of low concentration and high acidity, using the protonation of the ligand as the competition reaction of the complexation with U­(VI). depicts the representative spectrophotometric titrations. As shown in a, as UO2 2+ ions were added, the absorption bands of H2BiPDA in 275–285 nm decreased and concurrently those in 300–350 nm increased. Significant spectrum changes were also observed for the U­(VI)/​DmBiPDA and U­(VI)/​PhenDA titration systems (b,c). Excellent fitting was achieved, taking the absorption spectrum of U­(VI) into consideration. As shown in the right column of , nonlinear change of the fraction of the ligand species during the titration indicates the fittings are reliable and the obtained log β values () are trustworthy.

elements.content: Simulation with the HySS program showed that, in aqueous solution, the proton would not effectively compete with U­(VI) to react with L2– as we did in the DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O solution. Alternatively, inspired by literature work, we selected DTPA (diethylenetriaminepentaacetate) as the competing ligand of L2– to complex with U­(VI). The protonation constants of DTPA in 0.1 M NaClO4 are available in the NIST database, while the stability constants for the UO2 2+/​DTPA complexes have been reported elsewhere but at I = 3.0 M NaClO4. No data on the protonation of DTPA or its complexation with UO2 2+ in 0.1 M TEAP are available in the literature. Therefore, auxiliary potentiometric experiments were conducted in this work to determine the protonation constants of DTPA as well as the stability constants of UO2 2+/​DTPA complexes at I = 0.1 M TEAP, as described in the SI. The obtained protonation constants (see Figure S3 and Table S1 in the SI) are in excellent accordance with the literature data obtained in 0.1 M NaClO4. The stability constants of UO2 2+/​DTPA complexes at I = 0.1 M TEAP are determined as (Figure S4 and Table S2 in the SI): log β­(UO2­(DTPA)) = 15.42 ± 0.06, log β­(UO2­(HDTPA)) = 21.00 ± 0.04, log β­(UO2­(H2DTPA)) = 25.02 ± 0.02, and log β­(UO2­(OH)­(DTPA)) = 8.51 ± 0.10, which are consistent with the literature data considering the difference in ionic strength.
elements.clean_text:
In Aqueous Solution

Simulation with the HySS program showed that, in aqueous solution, the proton would not effectively compete with U(VI) to react with L2- as we did in the DMSO/20%(v)H2O solution. Alternatively, inspired by literature work, we selected DTPA (diethylenetriaminepentaacetate) as the competing ligand of L2- to complex with U(VI). The protonation constants of DTPA in 0.1 M NaClO4 are available in the NIST database, while the stability constants for the UO2 2+/DTPA complexes have been reported elsewhere but at I = 3.0 M NaClO4. No data on the protonation of DTPA or its complexation with UO2 2+ in 0.1 M TEAP are available in the literature. Therefore, auxiliary potentiometric experiments were conducted in this work to determine the protonation constants of DTPA as well as the stability constants of UO2 2+/DTPA complexes at I = 0.1 M TEAP, as described in the SI. The obtained protonation constants (see Figure S3 and Table S1 in the SI) are in excellent accordance with the literature data obtained in 0.1 M NaClO4. The stability constants of UO2 2+/DTPA complexes at I = 0.1 M TEAP are determined as (Figure S4 and Table S2 in the SI): log β(UO2(DTPA)) = 15.42 ± 0.06, log β(UO2(HDTPA)) = 21.00 ± 0.04, log β(UO2(H2DTPA)) = 25.02 ± 0.02, and log β(UO2(OH)(DTPA)) = 8.51 ± 0.10, which are consistent with the literature data considering the difference in ionic strength.

elements.content: shows the representative spectrophotometric titrations of UO2 2+/L (L = BiPDA, DmBiPDA, and PhenDA) solution with DTPA as the titrant. As shown in the left column of , the spectra of the solution changed regularly with the addition of DTPA, suggesting that free ligands BiPDA, DmBiPDA, or PhenDA were released from the UO2 2+/L complexes by DTPA and new UO2 2+/​DTPA complexes formed gradually in the solution. In conjunction with the aforementioned stability constants of UO2 2+/​DTPA complexes determined in this work and the hydrolysis constants of U­(VI) under the same conditions, the stability constants (log β) for UO2L­(aq) were calculated to be log β­(UO2­(BiPDA)) = 21.52 ± 0.08, log β­(UO2­(DmBiPDA)) = 18.72 ± 0.02, and log β­(UO2­(PhenDA)) = 22.81 ± 0.06. The speciation diagram shown in the right column of suggests that DTPA is an effective competing ligand of the three investigated ligands in complexation with U­(VI).

In conjunction with the aforementioned stability constants of UO2 2+/DTPA complexes determined in this work and the hydrolysis constants of U(VI) under the same conditions, the stability constants (log β) for UO2L(aq) were calculated to be log β(UO2(BiPDA)) = 21.52 ± 0.08, log β(UO2(DmBiPDA)) = 18.72 ± 0.02, and log β(UO2(PhenDA)) = 22.81 ± 0.06. The speciation diagram shown in the right column of  suggests that DTPA is an effective competing ligand of the three investigated ligands in complexation with U(VI).

elements.content: Crystal Structures of U­(VI) Complexes. [UO2(BiPDA)­(DMSO)]. [UO2­(BiPDA)­(DMSO)] is the 1:1 complex of U­(VI) with BiPDA crystallized in the monoclinic space group P21/c, and its structure is shown in a. The UO2 2+ cation is equatorially five-coordinated and chelated by one BiPDA anion and one DMSO molecule. The coordination environment of uranium is in the shape of a distorted pentagonal bipyramid (b). The BiPDA moiety binds to UO2 2+ in a tetradentate fashion through two aromatic N-donors and two carboxylate O-donors, while the DMSO molecule coordinates with U via the sulfoxide O-donor. Viewed down the c-axis, monomeric complexes arrange regularly in the a–b plane (b). c shows the plane-arranged complex layers extending along the c-axis to form the three-dimensional crystal structure by hydrogen bonds and π–π interactions.

elements.content: [UO2­(DmBiPDA)] n is the polymeric complex of U­(VI) with DmBiPDA crystallized in the monoclinic space group P21/n, and its structure is shown in a. The UO2 2+ cation is equatorially five-coordinated and chelated by two DmBiPDA anions. The DmBiPDA moiety is of pentadentate nature, binding to one UO2 2+ cation through two aromatic N-donors and two carboxylate O-donors, and to another adjacent UO2 2+ cation via an additional carboxylate O-donor. UO2 2+ cations are linked by DmBiPDA molecules to form an infinite electroneutral ribbon-like structure extending along the b-axis (b). Viewed along the c-axis, the ribbons assemble parallel to each other along the b-axis in the a–b plane (b). c shows the layers extending along the c-axis to form the three-dimensional crystal structure by weak electrostatic interactions such as hydrogen bonds and π–π interactions.

elements.content: Apart from the stability constant (log β = 22.81) of the UO2(PhenDA) complex in 0.1 M TEAP/H2O determined in this work, the stability constants of PhenDA complexes with some other lanthanides and actinides in 0.1 M NaClO4 have also been reported, for example, log β­([La­(PhenDA)]+) = 14.4 ± 0.1, log β­([Gd­(PhenDA)]+) = 17.0 ± 0.1, log β­([Th­(PhenDA)]2+) = 25.7 ± 0.9, and log β­([NpO2­(PhenDA)]−) = 11.73 ± 0.02. As we can see, the stability constants of these metal complexes follow the order of Th4+ > UO2 2+ > Gd3+ > La3+ > NpO2 +, which is in excellent agreement with the changing trend of the ionic potential (Z/r, where Z is the effective charge and r is the ionic radius) of these cations. With the known values of r (Å, CN = 6) (Th4+: 0.94, UO2 2+: 0.83, Gd3+: 0.938, La3+: 1.061, and NpO2 +: 0.88) and Z (Th4+: +4, UO2 2+: +3.2, Gd3+: +3, La3+: +3, and NpO2 +: +2.2), the ionic potentials are calculated to be 4.38, 3.86, 3.20, 2.83, and 2.50 for Th4+, UO2 2+, Gd3+, La3+, and NpO2 +, respectively. As shown in , a linear correlation between log βML and Z/r can be observed, suggesting that the interactions between PhenDA and these ions are predominantly ionic in nature, which is in agreement with that observed in the U­(VI) complexes with other ligands bearing O- and/or N-donors. Hancock and co-workers reported that two U­(VI) complexes formed with PhenDA by using hydroxyl ion as the competing reagent, and the stability constants were determined as log β­(UO2­(PhenDA)) = 16.5(1), and log β­(UO2­(OH)­(PhenDA)) = 5.2(1). Apparently, the value log β­(UO2­(PhenDA)) = 16.5(1) deviated significantly from the linear line shown in . Of course, this value is based on the reliability and accuracy of the hydrolysis constants used in the calculation, and those constants are known to be medium-dependent and highly diverse. We believe that the value of log β­(UO2­(PhenDA)) = 22.81(6) is reliable.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

Comparison of Binding Strength of PhenDA with UO2 2+, Ln3+, NpO2 +, and Th4+ 

Apart from the stability constant (log β = 22.81) of the UO2(PhenDA) complex in 0.1 M TEAP/H2O determined in this work, the stability constants of PhenDA complexes with some other lanthanides and actinides in 0.1 M NaClO4 have also been reported, for example, log β([La(PhenDA)]+) = 14.4 ± 0.1, log β([Gd(PhenDA)]+) = 17.0 ± 0.1, log β([Th(PhenDA)]2+) = 25.7 ± 0.9, and log β([NpO2(PhenDA)]-) = 11.73 ± 0.02. As we can see, the stability constants of these metal complexes follow the order of Th4+ > UO2 2+ > Gd3+ > La3+ > NpO2 +, which is in excellent agreement with the changing trend of the ionic potential (Z/r, where Z is the effective charge and r is the ionic radius) of these cations. With the known values of r (Å, CN = 6) (Th4+: 0.94, UO2 2+: 0.83, Gd3+: 0.938, La3+: 1.061, and NpO2 +: 0.88) and Z (Th4+: +4, UO2 2+: +3.2, Gd3+: +3, La3+: +3, and NpO2 +: +2.2), the ionic potentials are calculated to be 4.38, 3.86, 3.20, 2.83, and 2.50 for Th4+, UO2 2+, Gd3+, La3+, and NpO2 +, respectively. As shown in , a linear correlation between log βML and Z/r can be observed, suggesting that the interactions between PhenDA and these ions are predominantly ionic in nature, which is in agreement with that observed in the U(VI) complexes with other ligands bearing O- and/or N-donors. Hancock and co-workers reported that two U(VI) complexes formed with PhenDA by using hydroxyl ion as the competing reagent, and the stability constants were determined as log β(UO2(PhenDA)) = 16.5(1), and log β(UO2(OH)(PhenDA)) = 5.2(1). Apparently, the value log β(UO2(PhenDA)) = 16.5(1) deviated significantly from the linear line shown in . Of course, this value is based on the reliability and accuracy of the hydrolysis constants used in the calculation, and those constants are known to be medium-dependent and highly diverse. We believe that the value of log β(UO2(PhenDA)) = 22.81(6) is reliable.

elements.content: As shown in a, the absorption bands (380–550 nm) of U­(VI) in DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O solution are intensified as well as red-shifted as compared to those in aqueous solution. Such an observation confirms that strong interaction exists between U­(VI) and DMSO in DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O solution and some DMSO molecules are in the inner coordination sphere of the uranyl cation. As mentioned earlier, one DMSO molecule was found to coordinate with UO2 2+ through the sulfoxide oxygen atom in the complex UO2­(BiPDA)­(DMSO) (see a) obtained in DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O solution, validating the argument from a structural viewpoint. The strong solvation of UO2 2+ by DMSO well explains the relatively weaker U­(VI)/L complexes in DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O solution as compared to that in aqueous solution (). More energy is consumed to replace DMSO molecules from the inner coordination sphere of UO2 2+ by the ligand than to replace water molecules, which is not favorable for the complex formation. Despite the strengthened basicity of the ligand in DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O than in aqueous solution, it is not sufficient to override the negative effect from the strong solvation of UO2 2+ by DMSO.
elements.clean_text:
Comparison of U(VI) Complexes in Aqueous and DMSO/20%(v)H2O Solutions

As shown in a, the absorption bands (380-550 nm) of U(VI) in DMSO/20%(v)H2O solution are intensified as well as red-shifted as compared to those in aqueous solution. Such an observation confirms that strong interaction exists between U(VI) and DMSO in DMSO/20%(v)H2O solution and some DMSO molecules are in the inner coordination sphere of the uranyl cation. As mentioned earlier, one DMSO molecule was found to coordinate with UO2 2+ through the sulfoxide oxygen atom in the complex UO2(BiPDA)(DMSO) (see a) obtained in DMSO/20%(v)H2O solution, validating the argument from a structural viewpoint. The strong solvation of UO2 2+ by DMSO well explains the relatively weaker U(VI)/L complexes in DMSO/20%(v)H2O solution as compared to that in aqueous solution (). More energy is consumed to replace DMSO molecules from the inner coordination sphere of UO2 2+ by the ligand than to replace water molecules, which is not favorable for the complex formation. Despite the strengthened basicity of the ligand in DMSO/20%(v)H2O than in aqueous solution, it is not sufficient to override the negative effect from the strong solvation of UO2 2+ by DMSO.

elements.content: As shown in , the stability constant of UO2(PhenDA) is 1.3 logarithmic units higher than that of UO2­(BiPDA) in aqueous solution, which means the binding strength of U­(VI) with PhenDA is stronger than that with BiPDA even though PhenDA has weaker basicity than BiPDA. We attribute this result to the well-preorganized structure of PhenDA that could favor the complexation with metal ions. Moreover, the stability constants of UO2­(PhenDA) and UO2­(BiPDA) are all much higher than that of UO2­(EDDA). As is well-known, the N-donors in EDDA are sp3-hybridzed and quite different from the sp2-hybridized pyridyl N-donors in PhenDA and BiPDA. Therefore, we argue that BiPDA is the more suitable analogue ligand of PhenDA than EDDA in discussing the donor effect.
elements.clean_text:
Comparison of Binding Strength of BiPDA, PhenDA, and DmBiPDA with U(VI)

As shown in , the stability constant of UO2(PhenDA) is 1.3 logarithmic units higher than that of UO2(BiPDA) in aqueous solution, which means the binding strength of U(VI) with PhenDA is stronger than that with BiPDA even though PhenDA has weaker basicity than BiPDA. We attribute this result to the well-preorganized structure of PhenDA that could favor the complexation with metal ions. Moreover, the stability constants of UO2(PhenDA) and UO2(BiPDA) are all much higher than that of UO2(EDDA). As is well-known, the N-donors in EDDA are sp3-hybridzed and quite different from the sp2-hybridized pyridyl N-donors in PhenDA and BiPDA. Therefore, we argue that BiPDA is the more suitable analogue ligand of PhenDA than EDDA in discussing the donor effect.

elements.content: In DMSO/20%(v)­H2O, BiPDA is a stronger ligand than PhenDA in complexation with U­(VI), which is opposite to that observed in aqueous solution as discussed above. b depicts the spectra of BiPDA in DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O as well as in water under similar conditions. The absorption bands shifted from 310 nm in water to 286 nm in DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O; meanwhile, the absorption intensity increased. The spectra of DmBiPDA and PhenDA in DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O are also quite different from those in aqueous solution (see Figure S5 in the SI). These observations suggest that the solvation effect of DMSO and water on the ligands differs significantly and could have great impact on the conformations of the ligands. According to our DFT calculation results as shown in the SI, in aqueous solution, trans-BiPDA is 18.1 kJ/mol of energy lower than cis-BiPDA. In order to coordinate with UO2 2+, BiPDA needs no less than 420 kJ/mol to overide the rotational barrier from trans-BiPDA to cis-BiPDA. However, in DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O, trans-BiPDA is only 1.67 kJ/mol of energy lower than cis-BiPDA and the rotational barrier is 23.2 kJ/mol. Therefore, it is much easier for the transition of BiPDA from trans- to cis-conformation, the favored conformation when complexed with U­(VI), in DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O than in aqueous solution. In this case, we speculate that it is the relative basicity other than the preorgnization effect of BiPDA and PhenDA that plays the major role in determining the overall complexation strength with U­(VI), which makes UO2­(BiPDA) more stable than UO2­(PhenDA).

In order to coordinate with UO2 2+, BiPDA needs no less than 420 kJ/mol to overide the rotational barrier from trans-BiPDA to cis-BiPDA. However, in DMSO/20%(v)H2O, trans-BiPDA is only 1.67 kJ/mol of energy lower than cis-BiPDA and the rotational barrier is 23.2 kJ/mol. Therefore, it is much easier for the transition of BiPDA from trans- to cis-conformation, the favored conformation when complexed with U(VI), in DMSO/20%(v)H2O than in aqueous solution. In this case, we speculate that it is the relative basicity other than the preorgnization effect of BiPDA and PhenDA that plays the major role in determining the overall complexation strength with U(VI), which makes UO2(BiPDA) more stable than UO2(PhenDA).

elements.content: Both in aqueous and in DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O solutions, DmBiPDA shows the weakest binding strength with U­(VI), even though DmBiPDA has the strongest basicity and cis-DmBiPDA is the energy-favored conformation in both solutions (Table S3 in the SI). We could ascribe such an abnormality to the steric effect of methyls, which hinders the effective complexation between DmBiPDA and U­(VI). As we know, U­(VI) is a linear oxo cation and the donor atoms should bind to the U atom in the equatorial plane to ensure effective coordination. However, for DmBiPDA, the four N,O-donor atoms are hardly on the same plane due to the steric effect of methyl groups. The distortion of the U­(VI) equatorial plane is also confirmed in the crystal structure of the [UO2­(DmBiPDA)] n complex as disscussed in the following section.
elements.clean_text: Both in aqueous and in DMSO/20%(v)H2O solutions, DmBiPDA shows the weakest binding strength with U(VI), even though DmBiPDA has the strongest basicity and cis-DmBiPDA is the energy-favored conformation in both solutions (Table S3 in the SI). We could ascribe such an abnormality to the steric effect of methyls, which hinders the effective complexation between DmBiPDA and U(VI). As we know, U(VI) is a linear oxo cation and the donor atoms should bind to the U atom in the equatorial plane to ensure effective coordination. However, for DmBiPDA, the four N,O-donor atoms are hardly on the same plane due to the steric effect of methyl groups. The distortion of the U(VI) equatorial plane is also confirmed in the crystal structure of the [UO2(DmBiPDA)] n  complex as disscussed in the following section.

elements.content: lists selected bond lengths and angles of the compounds [UO2­(BiPDA)­(DMSO)]­and­[UO2­(DmBiPDA)] n . The corresponding values of [UO2­(PhenDA)] n ·nH2O are also listed for comparison. The detailed coordination modes between UO2 2+ and ligand in the three compounds are quite different. Both the two carboxylates of BiPDA in [UO2­(BiPDA)­(DMSO)] coordinate with UO2 2+ in the O​C-O-U mode, while in [UO2­(DmBiPDA)] n , only one carboxylate of the ligand coordinates with UO2 2+ in the O​C-O-U mode and the other bridges two UO2 2+ in the U-O­(bind)-C-O­(bind)-U mode. Moreover, in contrast to that the equatorial plane of UO2 2+ in [UO2­(BiPDA)­(DMSO)] was saturated by a solvent molecule, no solvent molecule but a carboxylate O atom from another ligand participates in coordination with the central UO2 2+ cation in [UO2­(DmBiPDA)] n . As a result, the compound [UO2­(BiPDA)­(DMSO)] was crystallized from the monomeric complex via hydrogen bonds and π–π interactions, while the compound [UO2­(DmBiPDA)] n was assembled as one-dimensional ribbons. The coordination modes in [UO2­(DmBiPDA)] n are commonly found in complexes of BiPDA and PhenDA with metal ions, such as Na2Ln2­(BiPDA)4­(H2O)2·3H2O (Ln = Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, and Yb), Ln3­(BiPDA)4­(H2O)2·12H2O (Ln = Ce, Nd, and Pr) and Ln2­(BiPDA)3­(H2O)3·3H2O (Ln = Er and Tm), and [UO2­(PhenDA)] n ·nH2O.

Comparison of U(VI) Complexes in Solid

  lists selected bond lengths and angles of the compounds [UO2(BiPDA)(DMSO)]and[UO2(DmBiPDA)] n . The corresponding values of [UO2(PhenDA)] n ⋅nH2O are also listed for comparison. The detailed coordination modes between UO2 2+ and ligand in the three compounds are quite different. Both the two carboxylates of BiPDA in [UO2(BiPDA)(DMSO)] coordinate with UO2 2+ in the OC-O-U mode, while in [UO2(DmBiPDA)] n , only one carboxylate of the ligand coordinates with UO2 2+ in the OC-O-U mode and the other bridges two UO2 2+ in the U-O(bind)-C-O(bind)-U mode. Moreover, in contrast to that the equatorial plane of UO2 2+ in [UO2(BiPDA)(DMSO)] was saturated by a solvent molecule, no solvent molecule but a carboxylate O atom from another ligand participates in coordination with the central UO2 2+ cation in [UO2(DmBiPDA)] n . As a result, the compound [UO2(BiPDA)(DMSO)] was crystallized from the monomeric complex via hydrogen bonds and π-π interactions, while the compound [UO2(DmBiPDA)] n  was assembled as one-dimensional ribbons. The coordination modes in [UO2(DmBiPDA)] n  are commonly found in complexes of BiPDA and PhenDA with metal ions, such as Na2Ln2(BiPDA)4(H2O)2⋅3H2O (Ln = Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, and Yb), Ln3(BiPDA)4(H2O)2⋅12H2O (Ln = Ce, Nd, and Pr) and Ln2(BiPDA)3(H2O)3⋅3H2O (Ln = Er and Tm), and [UO2(PhenDA)] n ⋅nH2O.

We note that there is no clear correlation between the complexation strength in solutions and the U–N/O bond lengths of the three solid complexes, suggesting that the charge on the N,O-donor atoms may not be a deciding factor determining the length and strength of the coordination bond in this system. Instead, the donor preorganization of the ligands plays an important role in the formation of the coordination bond. PhenDA in [UO2­(PhenDA)] n ·nH2O is in a low-strain fashion with all atoms from the ligand (see Figure S6), and BiPDA in [UO2­(BiPDA)­(DMSO)] also coordinates to UO2 2+ in a low-strain fashion, with only a small torsion angle (6.7°) between the square planes composed by the carboxyl groups and pyridine groups. In contrast, DmBiPDA in [UO2­(DmBiPDA)] n coordinates to UO2 2+ in a high-strain fashion. Because of the rotatable nature of the C–C single bond between the two pyridine units and the steric hindrance of the methyl groups, not all pyridyl atoms are in a plane and the torsion angle is about 43.7° between the square planes of the two methylpyridine moieties as well as 19.6° between the square planes of the methylpyridine and carboxylate. As result of this, not all the donor atoms from DmBiPDA in the one-dimensional ribbons locate in the same a–b plane, but they extend along the b-axis in a wavy-like shape (see ).

Instead, the donor preorganization of the ligands plays an important role in the formation of the coordination bond. PhenDA in [UO2(PhenDA)] n ⋅nH2O is in a low-strain fashion with all atoms from the ligand (see Figure S6), and BiPDA in [UO2(BiPDA)(DMSO)] also coordinates to UO2 2+ in a low-strain fashion, with only a small torsion angle (6.7°) between the square planes composed by the carboxyl groups and pyridine groups. In contrast, DmBiPDA in [UO2(DmBiPDA)] n  coordinates to UO2 2+ in a high-strain fashion. Because of the rotatable nature of the C-C single bond between the two pyridine units and the steric hindrance of the methyl groups, not all pyridyl atoms are in a plane and the torsion angle is about 43.7° between the square planes of the two methylpyridine moieties as well as 19.6° between the square planes of the methylpyridine and carboxylate. As result of this, not all the donor atoms from DmBiPDA in the one-dimensional ribbons locate in the same a-b plane, but they extend along the b-axis in a wavy-like shape (see ).

elements.content: The complexation behavior of U­(VI) with three tetradentate ligands, BiPDA, DmBiPDA, and PhenDA, was compared in aqueous and DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O solutions. The binding strength of PhenDA with representative actinides (Th4+, UO2 2+, and NpO2 +) and lanthanides (La3+ and Gd3+) correlates well with the charge density of the cations, implying that the binding is predominantly ionic in nature. The complexation strength of PhenDA with U­(VI) in aqueous solution is stronger than that of BiPDA as a result of its well-preorganized structure. In DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O solution, strong solvation of DMSO weakens the complexation of U­(VI) with the three ligands and reduces the difference between the trans- and cis-conformation of BiPDA, resulting in log β­(UO2­(BiPDA)) > log β­(UO2­(PhenDA)). The binding strength of DmBiPDA with UO2 2+ is the weakest in either aqueous solution or DMSO/​20%(v)­H2O, mainly due to the steric hindrance of methyl groups on DmBiPDDA. Single-crystal structural data of two novel complexes [UO2­(BiPDA)­(DMSO)] and [UO2­(DmBiPDA)] n indicate that ligands BiPDA and DmBiPDA coordinate with UO2 2+ via aromatic nitrogen atoms and carboxylate oxygen atoms, which is similar to that in the complex [UO2­(PhenDA)] n ·nH2O. Although there is no clear correlation between the complexation strength in solutions and the U–N/O bond lengths in solid complexes, the coordination modes and conformation of the ligands in the solid structures shed light on how a small change of the ligand structure would affect greatly the binding property with U­(VI) both in solution and in solid states. The thermodynamic and structural data for the [UO2L] (L = BiPDA, DmBiPDA, and PhenDA) complexes in this work help us further understand the role of donor preorganization on the binding strength with actinides as well as the role of the solvation of polar solvent like DMSO on the preorganization of donors, which is of significance to the designs of new extractants and extraction process.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The complexation behavior of U(VI) with three tetradentate ligands, BiPDA, DmBiPDA, and PhenDA, was compared in aqueous and DMSO/20%(v)H2O solutions. The binding strength of PhenDA with representative actinides (Th4+, UO2 2+, and NpO2 +) and lanthanides (La3+ and Gd3+) correlates well with the charge density of the cations, implying that the binding is predominantly ionic in nature. The complexation strength of PhenDA with U(VI) in aqueous solution is stronger than that of BiPDA as a result of its well-preorganized structure. In DMSO/20%(v)H2O solution, strong solvation of DMSO weakens the complexation of U(VI) with the three ligands and reduces the difference between the trans- and cis-conformation of BiPDA, resulting in log β(UO2(BiPDA)) > log β(UO2(PhenDA)). The binding strength of DmBiPDA with UO2 2+ is the weakest in either aqueous solution or DMSO/20%(v)H2O, mainly due to the steric hindrance of methyl groups on DmBiPDDA. Single-crystal structural data of two novel complexes [UO2(BiPDA)(DMSO)] and [UO2(DmBiPDA)] n  indicate that ligands BiPDA and DmBiPDA coordinate with UO2 2+ via aromatic nitrogen atoms and carboxylate oxygen atoms, which is similar to that in the complex [UO2(PhenDA)] n ⋅nH2O. Although there is no clear correlation between the complexation strength in solutions and the U-N/O bond lengths in solid complexes, the coordination modes and conformation of the ligands in the solid structures shed light on how a small change of the ligand structure would affect greatly the binding property with U(VI) both in solution and in solid states. The thermodynamic and structural data for the [UO2L] (L = BiPDA, DmBiPDA, and PhenDA) complexes in this work help us further understand the role of donor preorganization on the binding strength with actinides as well as the role of the solvation of polar solvent like DMSO on the preorganization of donors, which is of significance to the designs of new extractants and extraction process.

cln_elements.content: [UO2(BiPDA)­(DMSO)]: 0.05 mL of U­(VI) solution ([U] = 0.259 M, [HClO4] = 0.120 M) was evaporated to dryness at 120 °C on a hot plate, and then dissolved in 1.50 mL of DMSO/​20%H2O. 1.20 mL of 0.01 M BiPDA (neutralized by NaOH) in DMSO/​20%H2O was added. The mixed solution was shaken thoroughly and evaporated at room temperature. Yellowish green crystals appeared in about 5 months. [UO 2 (DmBiPDA)] n : 5.0 mL of an aqueous solution containing 3.91 × 10–3 mmol of DmBiPDA (neutralized by tetraethylammonium hydroxide) and 3.90 × 10–3 mmol of U­(VI) was refluxed at 150 °C on a hot plate for 2 h. Then the mixture was put aside on a hot plate at 100 °C. Yellowish green crystals appeared overnight.

Single-Crystal X-ray Diffractometry

Crystallization

 [UO2(BiPDA)(DMSO)]: 0.05 mL of U(VI) solution ([U] = 0.259 M, [HClO4] = 0.120 M) was evaporated to dryness at 120 °C on a hot plate, and then dissolved in 1.50 mL of DMSO/20%H2O. 1.20 mL of 0.01 M BiPDA (neutralized by NaOH) in DMSO/20%H2O was added. The mixed solution was shaken thoroughly and evaporated at room temperature. Yellowish green crystals appeared in about 5 months. [UO  2  (DmBiPDA)]   n  : 5.0 mL of an aqueous solution containing 3.91 × 10-3 mmol of DmBiPDA (neutralized by tetraethylammonium hydroxide) and 3.90 × 10-3 mmol of U(VI) was refluxed at 150 °C on a hot plate for 2 h. Then the mixture was put aside on a hot plate at 100 °C. Yellowish green crystals appeared overnight.
